{{Infobox company | name = Theranos | logo = Theranos Logo.svg | type = [[Privately held company|Privately held corporation]] |former_name=Real-Time Cures | foundation = 2003 | defunct = September 2018 | founder = [[Elizabeth Holmes]] | location_city = [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], [[California]] | location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = Elizabeth Holmes ([[Chairman]]), [[David Taylor (attorney)|David Taylor]] ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) | industry = [[Health care]] | products = [[Blood test]]s | services = [[Medical test]]s | equity = | owner = | fate = Shutdown and liquidated; founder indicted for wire fraud and conspiracy | homepage = {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828113917/https://theranos.com/|date=August 28, 2018|title=theranos.com}} | footnotes = <ref name="Mukherjee">{{cite news |last=Mukherjee |first=Sy |url=http://fortune.com/2018/04/10/theranos-layoffs-most-of-workforce/ |title=Report: Theranos Just Laid Off the Vast Majority of Its Employees |work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=2018-04-10 |accessdate=2018-04-11 }}</ref> }}
'''Theranos''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|θ|ɛr|ə|n|oʊ|s}}) was a [[privately held company|privately held]] [[health technology]] corporation<ref>{{cite web |title=Amended Statement by Foreign Corporation |url=https://businesssearch.sos.ca.gov/Document/RetrievePDF?Id=02651481-6312799 |website=California Secretary State Business Search |accessdate=23 July 2018 |format=pdf |date=April 21, 2004 |quote=C2651481}}</ref>, initially touted as a breakthrough technology company, but subsequently infamous for its false claims to have devised [[blood test]]s that only needed very small amounts of blood.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bilton |first1=Nick |title=Exclusive: How Elizabeth Holmes’s House of Cards Came Tumbling Down |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/09/elizabeth-holmes-theranos-exclusive |accessdate=3 December 2018 |publisher=Vanity Fair |date=6 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="BadBlood">{{cite book|author=John Carreyrou|title=Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CcJFDwAAQBAJ|date=21 May 2018|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-5247-3166-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Levine|first1=Matt|title=The Blood Unicorn Theranos Was Just a Fairy Tale|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2018-03-14/theranos-misled-investors-and-consumers-who-used-its-blood-test|accessdate=14 March 2018|work=Bloomberg View|date=14 March 2018}}</ref> Founded in 2003 by then-19-year-old [[Elizabeth Holmes]],<ref name="online">{{Cite news|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324123004579055003869574012/|title=Elizabeth Holmes: The Breakthrough of Instant Diagnosis|accessdate=2013-09-16|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|first=Joseph|last=Rago|date=2013-09-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019020214/http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324123004579055003869574012#|archive-date=2013-10-19|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Theranos raised more than [[US$]]700 million from venture capitalists and private investors,<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/theranos-from-unicorn-hype-to-massive-fraud-1521052226|title=Theranos: From Unicorn Hype to 'Massive Fraud'|last=Salzman|first=Avi|access-date=2018-03-31|language=en-US}}</ref> resulting in a $10 billion valuation at its peak in 2013 and 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/self-made-women/list/|title=America's Richest Self-Made Women|publisher=[[Forbes]]|access-date=}}{{failed verification|date=July 2018}}</ref><ref name="parloff">{{Cite news|title = This CEO is out for blood|url = http://fortune.com/2014/06/12/theranos-blood-holmes/|newspaper = [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|date = 2014-06-12|access-date = 2016-04-17|first = Roger|last = Parloff}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = The wildly hyped $9 billion blood test company that no one really understands|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonkblog/wp/2015/10/15/the-wildly-hyped-9-billion-blood-test-company-that-no-one-really-understands/|newspaper = [[The Washington Post]]|date = 2015-10-15|access-date = 2015-10-29|issn = 0190-8286|first = Carolyn Y.|last = Johnson}}</ref> Investors and the media hyped Theranos as a breakthrough in the large blood-testing market, where the US diagnostic-lab industry posts annual sales of over $70 billion. Theranos claimed its technology was revolutionary and that its tests required only about 1/100 to 1/1,000 of the amount of blood that would ordinarily be needed and cost far less than existing tests.
A turning point came in October 2015, when investigative reporter [[John Carreyrou]] of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' questioned the validity of Theranos' technology. Since then, the company has faced a string of legal and commercial challenges from medical authorities, investors, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC), [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] (CMS), state attorneys general, former business partners, patients, and others.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ableson|first1=Reed|title=Theranos Under Federal Criminal Investigation, Adding to Its Woes|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/19/business/theranos-sec-justice-department-investigation.html|accessdate=18 April 2018|work=New York Times|date=April 18, 2016}}</ref> By June 2016, it was estimated that Holmes' personal net worth had dropped from $4.5 billion to virtually nothing.<ref name="Forbes_nothing" /> The company was near [[bankruptcy]] until it received a $100 million investment from [[Fortress Investment Group]] in 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/blood-testing-firm-theranos-gets-100-million-lifeline-from-fortress-1514057523|title=Blood-Testing Firm Theranos Gets $100 Million Lifeline From Fortress|last1=Carreyrou|first1=John|date=24 December 2017|work=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=14 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=yes}}</ref> By 2018, the company was again close to going bankrupt.
In July 2016, Theranos received sanctions from the CMS, including the revocation of its [[Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments|CLIA]] certificate and prohibition of Holmes and other company officials from owning or operating a lab for two years.<ref name=carreyrou>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-regulator-bans-theranos-ceo-elizabeth-holmes-from-operating-labs-for-two-years-1467956064 |title=Theranos Dealt Sharp Blow as Elizabeth Holmes Is Banned From Operating Labs|last=Carreyrou|first=John|date=2016-07-08 |last2=Siconolfi|first2=Michael|newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]|issn=0099-9660|last3=Weaver|first3=Christopher|access-date=2016-07-09}}</ref> Theranos announced it would close its laboratory operations and wellness centers to work on miniature medical testing machines.<ref name="auto">{{cite news |title=Theranos to Close Labs and Lay Off 340 Workers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/06/business/theranos-to-close-labs-and-lay-off-340-workers.html|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=5 October 2016}}</ref> In April 2017, Theranos said it had reached a settlement agreement with CMS.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.theranos.com/2017/04/17/theranos-reaches-resolution-centers-medicare-medicaid-services/|title=Theranos Reaches Resolution with Centers For Medicare & Medicaid Services |publisher=Theranos Newsroom|date=17 April 2017}}</ref> Following the CMS sanctions, the [[Walgreens]] pharmacy chain terminated its contract with Theranos and filed a lawsuit claiming continuous [[Breach of contract|breaches of contract]]. The suit was [[settled out of court]], with Theranos compensating Walgreens for a much smaller amount than the claimed $140 million, reported at about $30 million.
On March 14, 2018, Theranos, Holmes, and former company president [[Ramesh Balwani|Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani]] were charged with "massive [[fraud]]" by the SEC.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2018/03/14/theranos-founder-elizabeth-holmes-charged-massive-fraud/424670002/|title=Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes charged with 'massive fraud'|publisher=USA Today}}</ref> One section of the complaint says Holmes falsely claimed in 2014 that the company had annual revenues of $100 million, a thousand times more than the actual figure of $100,000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/14/theranos-president-exaggerated-revenue-by-1000x-says-sec.html|title=Theranos president exaggerated the company's revenue by 1,000x to investors, says SEC|last=Aiello|first=Chloe|date=2018-03-14|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-05-26}}</ref> Theranos and Holmes agreed to resolve the charges against them, with Holmes paying a fine of $500,000, returning the remaining 18.9 million shares that she held, relinquishing her control of the company, and being barred from being an officer or director of any [[public company]] for ten years.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/14/health/theranos-elizabeth-holmes-fraud.html|title=Elizabeth Holmes, Theranos C.E.O. and Silicon Valley Star, Accused of Fraud|last1=Thomas|first1=Katie|date=14 March 2018|work=New York Times|accessdate=14 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2018/03/14/theranos-founder-elizabeth-holmes-charged-massive-fraud/424670002/|title=Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes charged with 'massive fraud'|work=USA Today|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en}}</ref> According to the agreement, if Theranos were acquired or otherwise [[liquidation|liquidated]], Holmes would not profit from her ownership until more than $750 million was returned to investors and other preferred shareholders. Theranos and Holmes neither admitted nor denied the allegations in the SEC's complaint.<ref name=":1" /> Balwani did not settle.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/14/theranos-ceo-holmes-and-former-president-balwani-charged-with-massive-fraud.html|title=Theranos CEO Holmes and former president Balwani charged with massive fraud|last=Balakrishnan|first=Anita|date=2018-03-14|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-05-26}}</ref> On June 15, 2018, the [[United States Attorney for the Northern District of California|U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of California]] announced the indictment of Holmes on [[wire fraud]] and conspiracy charges. Balwani was also indicted on the same charges.<ref>{{cite web |last1=O'Brien |first1=Sarah Ashley |title=Elizabeth Holmes indicted on wire fraud charges, steps down from Theranos |url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/06/15/technology/elizabeth-holmes-indicted-theranos/index.html |website=CNN.com |publisher=CNN |accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref>
Theranos ceased operations on August 31, 2018, with CEO David Taylor and a few support staff remaining on payroll for a few more days.<ref>https://www.wsj.com/articles/blood-testing-firm-theranos-to-dissolve-1536115130</ref>
==History==
While at [[Stanford University]], Elizabeth Holmes had an idea to develop a wearable patch that could adjust the dosage of drug delivery and notify doctors of variables in patients' blood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/201510/kimberly-weisul/the-longest-game.html|title=How Playing the Long Game Made Elizabeth Holmes a Billionaire|work=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|date=October 2015|access-date=3 September 2016|author=Weisul, Kimberly}}</ref> She started developing [[lab-on-a-chip]] technology for blood tests, and had the idea for a company that would make testing cheaper, more convenient and accessible to consumers.<ref name=never>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/print-edition/2013/08/30/theranos-the-biggest-biotech-youve.html|title=Theranos: The biggest biotech you've never heard of|last=Leuty|first=Ron|date=30 August 2013|work=San Francisco Business Times|accessdate=9 March 2014}}</ref> Holmes dropped out of Stanford and used the education trust from her parents to found the company that would later be called Theranos, derived from a combination of the words "therapy" and "diagnosis".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2014/02/elizabeth-holmes-theranos/|title=This Woman Invented a Way to Run 30 Lab Tests on Only One Drop of Blood|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=18 February 2014|access-date=27 September 2016|author=Roper, Caitlin}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pharmacytimes.com/contributor/beth-bolt-rph/2014/11/bringing-painless-blood-testing-to-the-pharmacy|title=Bringing Painless Blood Testing to the Pharmacy|work=[[Pharmacy Times]]|date=14 November 2014|access-date=27 September 2016|author=Bolt, Beth}}</ref> The company's original name was '''Real-Time Cures''',<ref name="parloff" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-history-of-silicon-valley-unicorn-theranos-and-ceo-elizabeth-holmes-2018-5|title=The rise and fall of Theranos, the blood-testing startup that went from a rising star in Silicon Valley to facing fraud charges over a wild 15-year span|work=[[Business Insider]]|date=May 25, 2018|access-date=June 11, 2018|author1=Hu, Charlotte|author2=Ramsey, Lydia}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/05/everything-need-know-theranos-saga-far/|title=Everything You Need to Know About the Theranos Saga So Far|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=May 4, 2016|access-date=June 11, 2018|author=Stockton, Nick}}</ref> which Holmes changed after deciding that too many people were dubious about the word "cure".<ref name="parloff" />
===Partnerships=== In September 2013, Theranos partnered with Walgreens to offer in-store blood tests at more than 40 locations. Walgreens announced plans to expand the "wellness centers" across the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/11/18/walgreens-blood-tests/|title=Walgreens to offer affordable and needle-free blood tests in more stores (updated)|work=[[Business Insider]]|date=18 November 2014|access-date=4 September 2016|author=Moon, Mariella}}</ref> Theranos blood tests were used on drug trial patients of [[GlaxoSmithKline]] and [[Pfizer]]. Each company stated that there were no ongoing active projects with Theranos in October 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21656196-theranos-ambitious-silicon-valley-firm-wants-shake-up-market-medical|title=Young blood|work=[[The Economist]]|date=27 June 2015|access-date=4 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="Duhaime-Ross">{{Cite web|title = Theranos didn't work with the huge drug company it supposedly made money from, drug company says|last=Duhaime-Ross|first=Arielle|date=2015-10-26|url = https://www.theverge.com/2015/10/26/9618390/Theranos-glaxosmithkline-denies-partnership-pfizer-blood-test|website = The Verge|accessdate = 2015-10-29}}</ref> In November 2016, Walgreen Co. filed suit against Theranos in a federal court in Delaware, for breach of contract. Theranos reported to investors on June 21, 2017 that the suit, which originally sought $140 million in damages, was settled for less than $30 million.<ref>Weaver, Christopher, John Carreyrou and Michael Siconolfi, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/walgreens-seeks-to-recover-140-million-investment-from-theranos-1478642410 "Walgreen Sues Theranos, Seeks $140 Million in Damages"], ''Wall Street Journal'', November 8, 2016.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/21/theranos-walgreens-reportedly-reach-a-deal-to-settle-suit-for-under-30-million.html|title=Theranos, Walgreens reportedly reach a deal to settle suit for under $30 million|last=Thomas|first=Lauren|date=2017-06-21|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref>
In March 2015 the [[Cleveland Clinic]] announced a partnership with Theranos to test its technology in order to decrease the cost of lab tests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/4100844587001/theranos-cleveland-clinic-ceos-on-innovation-partnership-/?#sp=show-clips|title=Theranos, Cleveland Clinic CEO's on innovation partnership|work=[[Fox Business]]|date=9 March 2015|access-date=4 September 2016}}</ref> Theranos became the lab-work provider for Pennsylvania insurers, AmeriHealth Caritas and Capital BlueCross, in July 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/philadelphia/morning_roundup/2015/07/amerihealth-caritas-theranos-lab-test-low-income.html|title=Philadelphia health insurer to make lab testing easier for Medicaid members|work=[[Philadelphia Business Journal]]|date=16 July 2016|access-date=4 September 2016|author=George, John}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-07-08/fingerprick-lab-test-startup-theranos-strikes-insurance-deal|title=Fingerprick Lab Test Startup Theranos Strikes Insurance Deal|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=8 July 2015|access-date=4 September 2016|author1=Chen, Caroline|author2=Tracer, Zachary}}</ref>
In July 2015, the [[Food and Drug Administration]] approved the use of the company's fingerstick blood testing device for the [[herpes simplex virus]] (HSV-1) outside a clinical laboratory setting.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Parloff|first1=Roger|title=Disruptive diagnostics firm Theranos gets boost from FDA|url=http://fortune.com/2015/07/02/theranos-fda-approval/|accessdate=16 July 2015|publisher=Fortune Magazine|date=2 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconbeat.com/2015/07/16/theranos-gets-another-fda-approval-for-its-blood-test/|title=Theranos gets another FDA approval for its blood test|work=Silicon Beat|date=16 July 2015|access-date=27 September 2016|author=Quinn, Michelle}}</ref> Theranos was awarded the 2015 Bioscience Company of the Year by AzBio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azbio.org/azbio-awards-2015|title=AZBio Awards 2015|publisher=AzBio.org|date=2015|access-date=27 September 2016}}</ref>
===Exposure and downfall=== In October 2015, [[John Carreyrou]] of the ''The Wall Street Journal'' reported that Theranos was using traditional blood testing machines to run its tests instead of the company's Edison devices, and that the company's Edison machines might provide inaccurate results.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/09/elizabeth-holmes-theranos-exclusive|title=Exclusive: How Elizabeth Holmes's House of Cards Came Tumbling Down|last=Bilton|first=Nick|work=The Hive|access-date=2017-04-22|language=en}}</ref> <ref name=":0">{{Cite news|title = Hot Startup Theranos Has Struggled With Its Blood-Test Technology|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/theranos-has-struggled-with-blood-tests-1444881901|newspaper = Wall Street Journal|access-date = 2015-10-29|issn = 0099-9660|first = John|last = Carreyrou}}</ref> Theranos claimed that the allegations were "factually and scientifically erroneous and grounded in baseless assertions by inexperienced and disgruntled former employees and industry incumbents".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Report Claims Theranos Struggling With Blood Test Tech|url = http://fortune.com/2015/10/15/theranos-blood-tests-wsj/|website = Fortune|accessdate = 2015-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://recode.net/2015/10/22/theranos-attacks-wall-street-journal-again-in-a-rebuttal-youll-need-a-medical-degree-to-understand/|title=Theranos Attacks Wall Street Journal (Again) in a Rebuttal You'll Need a Medical Degree to Understand|author=Dawn Chmielewski|work=[[Re/code]]|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref> Walgreens suspended plans to expand blood-testing centers in their stores following the report.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Walgreens halts expansion of Theranos centers | work = Fortune Magazine | date = 24 October 2015 | accessdate = 2015-10-25 | url=http://fortune.com/2015/10/24/walgreens-theranos/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/11/21/in-defense-of-theranos/ | title=In Defense Of Theranos | publisher=TechCrunch | date=21 November 2015 | accessdate=23 October 2016 | author=Rosenbloom, Micah}}</ref> At that time, the Cleveland Clinic announced that it would work to verify Theranos technology.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/10/30/well-work-to-verify-theranos-technology-cleveland-clinic-ceo.html | title=We'll test Theranos tech: Cleveland Clinic CEO | publisher=CNBC | date=30 October 2015 | accessdate=23 October 2016 | author=DiChristopher, Tom}}</ref> Theranos fought back against the ''Journal''<nowiki>'s</nowiki> investigation, sending lawyers after sources in the story in an effort to stop them from providing information to the press.<ref name="BadBlood" /? Tyler Shultz was a key source for the WSJ story. Schultz was a Theranos employee from 2013 to 14 and the grandson of one-time Theranos director [[George P. Shultz]]. Tyler Shultz had attempted to bring concerns about the company's activities to his management, and when that had failed, he had spoken to Carreyrou and also, under an alias, reported the company the New York State Department of Health.<ref name=WSJ1116>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/theranos-whistleblower-shook-the-companyand-his-family-1479335963|title=Theranos Whistleblower Shook the Company{{snd}}And His Family| last=Carreyrou| first=John| date=2016-11-17| work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=2016-11-17}}</ref>
Following the WSJ story, the history of FDA interactions with Theranos were scrutinized. The FDA had received a formal inquiry to look at Theranos blood test devices by the U.S. Department of Defense in 2012 before the devices were commercially available and did not require FDA approval.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2015/12/02/internal-emails-reveal-concerns-about-theranoss-fda-compliance-date-back-years/?tid=pm_business_pop_b|title=E-mails reveal concerns about Theranos's FDA compliance date back years|first = Carolyn Y.|last = Johnson|date=2 December 2015|work=[[Washington Post]]|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref> FDA inspection reports from 2014 and 2015 stated that its containers for blood collection were "not validated under actual or simulated use conditions" and "were not reviewed and not approved by designated individual(s) prior to issuance".<ref>{{Cite news | title = The FDA's notes from its visit to Theranos' labs don't look good | work = Business Insider | date = 27 October 2015 | accessdate = 2015-10-27 | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fda-documents-on-theranos-2015-10}}</ref> The FDA inspection in 2015 resulted in multiple [[Form_FDA_483|483]]'s from the FDA where inspectors observed violations of [[Title_21_of_the_Code_of_Federal_Regulations|FDA Title 21 Regulations]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.fda.gov/downloads/AboutFDA/CentersOffices/OfficeofGlobalRegulatoryOperationsandPolicy/ORA/ORAElectronicReadingRoom/UCM469396.pdf | title = FDA-483 | date = 16 September 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.fda.gov/downloads/AboutFDA/CentersOffices/OfficeofGlobalRegulatoryOperationsandPolicy/ORA/ORAElectronicReadingRoom/UCM469395.pdf |title = FDA-483 | date = 16 September 2015 }}</ref> After the inspection, Theranos announced that it would voluntarily suspend its tests apart from the FDA-approved herpes simplex virus (HSV-1) test.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/98407/20151022/blood-testing-start-up-theranos-is-in-pause-period-says-ceo-elizabeth-holmes.htm | title=Blood-Testing Start-Up Theranos Is In 'Pause Period', Says CEO Elizabeth Holmes | publisher=Tech Times | date=22 October 2015 | accessdate=23 October 2016 | author=Derla, Katherine}}</ref>
The [[Arizona Department of Health Services]] reported issues with the company's Scottsdale lab meeting regulations in October 2015.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Theranos suspends micro blood tests to allow FDA review | work = AZ Central| date = October 25, 2015 | accessdate = 2015-10-26 | url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/arizona/investigations/2015/10/25/theranos-suspends-micro-blood-tests-allow-fda-review/74355082/}}{{dead link|date=July 2018}}</ref>
In January 2016, the [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] (CMS) sent a letter to Theranos based on an inspection of its Newark, California, lab in the Fall of 2015, reporting that the facility did not "comply with certificate requirements and performance standards" and caused an "immediate jeopardy to patient health and safety" due to a test to determine the correct dose of the blood-thinning drug [[warfarin]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = US government says Theranos lab poses 'immediate jeopardy to patient safety'|url = https://www.theverge.com/2016/1/27/10853340/government-says-theranos-lab-poses-immediate-threat-to-public-safety|website = The Verge|access-date = 2016-01-27}}</ref> Walgreens and Capital BlueCross announced a suspension of Theranos blood tests from the Newark lab.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/capital-bluecross-and-theranos-2016-1 | title=Another partner just asked Theranos to stop running blood tests | publisher=Business Insider | date=29 January 2016 | accessdate=23 October 2016 | author=Ramsey, Lydia}}</ref>
In March 2016, CMS regulators announced plans to enact sanctions that included suspending Holmes and Balwani from owning or operating a lab for two years and that they would revoke the lab's license.<ref name="nytimes.com">{{Cite web|title = Theranos Under Fire as U.S. Threatens Crippling Sanctions|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/14/business/theranos-elizabeth-holmes-proposed-ban.html?_r=0|website = New York Times|access-date = 2016-04-19}}</ref> The company did not receive the sanctions until July.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/cms-wants-to-ban-elizabeth-holmes-from-theranos-for-2-years-2016-4 | title=US regulators want to bar Elizabeth Holmes from Theranos for 2 years | publisher=Business Insider | date=13 April 2016 | accessdate=23 October 2016 | author=Ramsey, Lydia}}</ref>
By April 2016 Theranos came under criminal investigation by federal prosecutors and the SEC for allegedly misleading investors and government officials about its technology.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/27/opinion/dont-blame-silicon-valley-for-theranos.html|title=Don't Blame Silicon Valley for Theranos|date=27 April 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=1 June 2016}}</ref> The case is considered "extremely unusual" by a former assistant U.S. attorney for the Justice Department.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Federal-criminal-probe-of-Theranos-rings-hollow-7463023.php | title=Federal criminal probe of Theranos rings hollow | publisher=San Francisco Chronicle | date=11 May 2016 | accessdate=23 October 2016 | author=Lee, Thomas}}</ref> The U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Energy and Commerce requested information on what Theranos was doing to correct its testing inaccuracies and adherence to federal guidelines in June 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.healthcarefinancenews.com/news/theranos-founder-elizabeth-holmes-asked-congressional-committee-detail-companys-compliance|title=Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes asked by Congressional committee to detail company's compliance efforts|last=Lagasse|first=Jeff|date=2016-07-01|website=Healthcare Finance News|access-date=2016-07-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-01/theranos-queried-on-blood-test-failures-by-house-democrats|title=Theranos Queried on Blood Test Failures by House Democrats|first=Zachary |last=Tracer|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref>
In May 2016, Theranos announced that it had voided two years of results from its Edison device.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/theranos-voids-two-years-of-edison-blood-test-results-1463616976|title=Theranos Voids Two Years of Edison Blood-Test Results|last=Carreyrou|first=John|date=2016-05-19|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-05-21}}</ref> The company announced that about 1 percent of test results had been voided or corrected from its proprietary machines in June 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-06-03/theranos-says-only-1-of-results-affected-some-doubt-tests|title=Theranos Says Only 1% of Results Affected; Some Doubt Tests|author1=Caroline Chen|author2=Rebecca Spalding|date=June 3, 2016|accessdate=June 29, 2016|website=Bloomberg.com}}</ref>
In July 2016, Theranos announced that the CMS had revoked its CLIA certificate and issued sanctions prohibiting its owners and operators from owning or operating a lab for two years, suspension of approval to receive Medicare and Medicaid payments, and a civil monetary penalty. The company discontinued testing at its Newark location while attempting to resolve the issues.<ref name=carreyrou/> Theranos announced plans to appeal the decision by regulators to revoke its license to operate a lab in California and other sanctions.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/theranos-to-appeal-regulatory-sanctions-1472192782 "Theranos to Appeal Regulatory Sanctions"] ''Wall Street Journal'', Retrieved 26 August 2016.</ref>
In August 2016 the company withdrew its request for emergency clearance of a [[Zika virus]] blood test after a lack of essential safeguards during the testing process was found by federal inspectors.<ref>{{cite news|title=Troubled Theranos hits another wall as Zika test withdrawn|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/08/31/theranos-zika-test-withdrawn-after-regulators-flag-problems/|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=31 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/theranos-halts-new-zika-test-after-fda-inspection-1472598332|title=Theranos Halts New Zika Test After FDA Inspection|first1=John|last1=Carreyrou|first2=Christopher|last2=Weaver|date=30 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2016|via=Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
Theranos announced that it would close its laboratory operations, wellness centers and lay off about 40 percent of its work force to work on miniature medical testing machines in October 2016.<ref name="auto"/><ref name=open>{{cite news|title=An Open Letter From Elizabeth Holmes|url=https://news.theranos.com/2016/10/05/an-open-letter-elizabeth-holmes/|accessdate=6 October 2016|website=theranos.com| date=5 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-theranos-layoffs-20161006-story.html|title=Theranos will close labs and Walgreens testing sites, laying off hundreds|first=Washington|last=Post|work=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mole|first1=Beth|title=Theranos throws in the towel on clinical labs, officially pivots to devices|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2016/10/theranos-throws-in-the-towel-on-clinical-labs-officially-pivots-to-devices/|accessdate=6 October 2016|publisher=Ars Technica|date=5 October 2016}}</ref><ref name=open/>
In January 2017, Theranos announced that it had laid off 41% of its workforce, or approximately 155 people and closed the last remaining blood-testing facility after the lab failed a second major U.S. regulatory inspection.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/second-theranos-lab-failed-u-s-inspection-1484708428|title=Second Theranos Lab Failed U.S. Inspection|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|author=Christopher Weaver|date=17 January 2017|access-date=18 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/01/17/theranos-last-lab-inspection-test-fail/|title=Theranos closes its last remaining blood-testing lab after it reportedly failed an inspection|publisher=TechCrunch|author=Jon Russell|date=18 January 2017|access-date=18 January 2017}}</ref>
Also that month, the company faced lawsuits from several different entities including Walgreens<ref name=cnn-wal>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/01/06/technology/theranos-layoffs-41-percent/index.html|title=Theranos fires 41% of staffers|first=Sara Ashley|last=O'Brien|date=6 January 2017|work=cnn.com|accessdate=10 January 2017}}</ref><ref name=chicago-tribune>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-theranos-fires-staff-20170106-story.html|title=Theranos to fire 41 percent of workforce in second round of cuts|first=Caroline|last=Chen|work=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=10 January 2017}}</ref> and the [[Arizona Attorney General]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Arizona AG plans to sue Theranos over blood-testing devices|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-theranos-lawsuit-arizona-idUSKBN14W2IW?feedType=RSS&feedName=healthNews|website=Reuters|accessdate=12 January 2017|date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
In April 2017, lawyers for Partner Investments LP and two other funds, with combined stakes totaling more than $96 million in Theranos preferred shares, charged that Theranos had threatened to seek [[Chapter 11 Bankruptcy|bankruptcy protection]] if the investors did not agree to accept additional stock equity in lieu of litigation. Theranos officials said the funds had mischaracterized the exchange offer, which was discussed before the suit was filed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-19/theranos-investors-say-they-were-pressured-to-abandon-lawsuit|title=Theranos Investors Say They Were Pressured to Abandon Lawsuit|date=2017-04-19|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-04-20}}</ref> The suit also alleged that Theranos Inc. had misled company directors about its practices concerning laboratory testing and that it had secretly bought lab equipment to run fake demonstrations.<ref name=wsj-weaver>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/theranos-secretly-bought-outside-lab-gear-ran-fake-tests-court-filings-1492794470|title=Theranos Secretly Bought Outside Lab Gear, Ran Fake Tests: Court Filings|last=Weaver|first=Christopher|date=2017-04-22|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-04-22|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> The case was settled on May 1, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.theranos.com/2017/05/01/theranos-reaches-settlement-partner-fund-management|title=Theranos Reaches Steelement with Partner Fund Management|publisher= Theranos Newsroom|date=1 May 2017|website=theranos.com|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref> On May 1, 2017, Theranos announced that it had reached an undisclosed settlement with Partner Fund Management LP. Theranos General Counsel David Taylor stated: "Theranos is pleased to have resolved both lawsuits with PFM. Although we are confident that we would have prevailed at trial, resolution of these two cases allows our tender offer to go forward and enables us to return our focus where it belongs, which is on executing our business plans and delivering value for our shareholders."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.theranos.com/2017/05/01/theranos-reaches-settlement-partner-fund-management/|title=Theranos Reaches Settlement with Partner Fund Management|date=2017-05-01|publisher=Theranos Newsroom|access-date=2017-05-02}}</ref>
Also in April 2017, Theranos reached a settlement with CMS agreeing to stay out of the blood-testing business for at least two years in exchange for reduced penalties,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/theranos-agrees-to-2-year-ban-on-clinical-blood-work-2017-04-17|title=Theranos agrees to 2-year ban on clinical blood work|last=Weaver|first=Christopher|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2017-04-28|language=en-US}}</ref> and signed a [[consent decree]] with the [[Government of Arizona|state of Arizona]] over violations of the [[Arizona Consumer Fraud Act]]. Alleged violations included [[false advertisement]] and inaccurate blood testing. Theranos agreed to refund $4.65 million to the state's residents for Theranos blood testing services, regardless of whether the test results were voided or corrected.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.theranos.com/2017/04/18/theranos-arizona-attorney-general-reach-agreement-full-restitution-state-consumers/|title=Theranos, Arizona Attorney General Reach Agreement on Full Restitution to State Consumers |publisher=Theranos Newsroom|date=18 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mole|first1=Beth|title=With $4.65M deal, Arizonans will get their money back from Theranos|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2017/04/with-4-65m-deal-arizonans-will-get-their-money-back-from-theranos/|accessdate=18 April 2017|publisher=Ars Technica|date=18 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="Mukherjee fortune">Sy Mukherjee, [http://fortune.com/2017/05/16/theranos-news-investors/ Theranos Just Reached a Deal With Investors to Avoid Lawsuits] ''Fortune'', May 16, 2017</ref><ref>Howard Fischer, [http://www.wmicentral.com/news/latest_news/theranos-will-refund-m-to-arizonans-who-took-its-blood/article_29c0632f-29ad-5a32-9137-0c905257f4ab.html Theranos will refund $4.6M to Arizonans who took its blood tests] ''White Mountain Independent'' April 21, 2017</ref>
In August 2017, Theranos announced it had reached a settlement with Walgreens.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.theranos.com/2017/08/01/theranos-reaches-settlement-walgreens/|title=Theranos Reaches Settlement with Walgreens|date=1 August 2017|publisher=Theranos Newsroom}}</ref>
In December 2017, Fortress Investment Group loaned $100 million to Theranos. Theranos had reportedly been on the verge of bankruptcy, with the loan meant to keep the company solvent into 2018.<ref name=wsj-carreyrou2>{{cite news |last=Carreyrou |first=John |date=December 24, 2017 |title=Blood-Testing Firm Theranos Gets $100 Million Lifeline From Fortress |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/blood-testing-firm-theranos-gets-100-million-lifeline-from-fortress-1514057523 | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |location= |access-date=January 15, 2018}}</ref><ref name=fortune-theranos>{{cite news |last=Morris |first=David Z. |date=December 23, 2017 |title=Theranos Secures $100 Million in New Funding from Fortress Capital |url=http://fortune.com/2017/12/23/theranos-secures-100-million-in-new-funding-from-fortress-capital/ | work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |location= |access-datejanuary 15, 2018=}}</ref><ref name=cnbc-loan>{{cite news |last=Sheetz |first=Michael |date=December 26, 2017 |title=Theranos dodges bankruptcy after $100 million loan: Report |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/12/26/theranos-dodges-bankruptcy-after-100-million-loan-report.html | work=[[CNBC]] |location= |access-date=January 15, 2018}}</ref> On April 10, 2018, the company laid off the majority of workers in a renewed bid to avoid bankruptcy. The company's total headcount was down to fewer than 25 employees, after having 800 employees at its peak.<ref name="Mukherjee" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Theranos Lays Off Most Of Its Workforce|url=https://www.pymnts.com/news/security-and-risk/2018/theranos-layoff-bankruptcy-fraud-sec/|accessdate=12 April 2018|work=PYMNTS|date=April 11, 2018}}</ref>
In March 2018 the US Securities and Exchange Commission charged Theranos, its CEO Elizabeth Holmes and former president Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani, claiming they had engaged in an "elaborate, years-long fraud" wherein they "deceived investors into believing that its key product – a portable blood analyzer – could conduct comprehensive blood tests from finger drops of blood."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2018/03/14/theranos-chief-executive-elizabeth-holmes-charged-with-massive-fraud/|title=Theranos chief executive Elizabeth Holmes charged with massive fraud|first=Carolyn Y.|last=Johnson|date=14 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.washingtonpost.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/litigation/complaints/2018/comp-pr2018-41-theranos-holmes.pdf|title=Securities and Exchange Commission, vs. Elizabeth Holmes and Theranos, Inc., Complaint |website=sec.gov|publisher=SEC|accessdate=14 March 2018}}</ref> Holmes reached a settlement with the SEC, which requires her to pay $500,000, forfeit 19 million shares of company stock, and be barred from having a leadership position in any public company for ten years.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Robinson|first1=Matt|title=Theranos and CEO Elizabeth Holmes Accused of Fraud by SEC|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-14/theranos-ceo-holmes-accused-of-fraud-by-sec-jeraxw6a|accessdate=14 March 2018|work=Bloomberg News|date=14 March 2018}}</ref> Balwani did not settle with the SEC.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Balakrishnan|first1=Anita|title=Theranos CEO Holmes and former president Balwani charged with massive fraud|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/14/theranos-ceo-holmes-and-former-president-balwani-charged-with-massive-fraud.html|accessdate=14 March 2018|work=CNBC|date=14 March 2018}}</ref>
On June 15, 2018, Holmes and Balwani were [[Indictment|indicted]] on multiple counts of [[Mail and wire fraud|wire fraud]] and conspiracy to commit wire fraud. According to the indictment, investors and doctors and patients were defrauded. It is alleged the defendants were aware of the unreliability and inaccuracy of their products, but concealed that information. If convicted, they each face a maximum fine of $250,000 and 20 years in prison. The case has been assigned to [[Lucy H. Koh]], [[United States federal judge|United States District Judge]] of the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California]].<ref name="Justice61618">{{cite web |title=Theranos Founder and Former Chief Operating Officer Charged In Alleged Wire Fraud Schemes |url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-ndca/pr/theranos-founder-and-former-chief-operating-officer-charged-alleged-wire-fraud-schemes |website=justice.gov |publisher=United States Department of Justice |accessdate=June 16, 2018 |format=press release |date=June 15, 2018 |quote=Elizabeth Holmes and Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani Are Alleged To Have Perpetrated Multi-million Dollar Schemes To Defraud Investors, Doctors, and Patients.}}</ref><ref>http://money.cnn.com/2018/06/15/technology/elizabeth-holmes-indicted-theranos/index.html</ref>
=== Shutdown === On September 4, 2018, Theranos announced in an email to investors that it would cease operations and release its assets and remaining cash to creditors after all efforts to find a buyer came to nothing. Most of the company's remaining employees were laid off on the previous Friday, August 31. However, CEO David Taylor and a few support staffers remained on payroll for a few more days.<ref name="TheranosShutdown">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/blood-testing-firm-theranos-to-dissolve-1536115130|last1=Carreyrou|first1=John|title=Blood-Testing Firm Theranos to Dissolve|publisher=Wall Street Journal}}</ref> At the time the Theranos website was inaccessible. The Wall Street Journal reported that any equity investments in the company were made worthless by the shutdown.
==Technology and products== Theranos claimed to have developed devices to automate and miniaturize blood tests using microscopic blood volumes. Theranos dubbed its blood collection vessel the "nanotainer" and its analysis machine the "Edison."<ref name=rago>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324123004579055003869574012|title=Elizabeth Holmes: The Breakthrough of Instant Diagnosis|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=8 September 2013|access-date=25 July 2016|author=Rago, Joseph}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Nguyen|first1=Tuan C.|title=How To Run 30 Health Tests On a Single Drop of Blood|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/innovation/how-to-run-30-health-tests-on-a-single-drop-of-blood-180949983|website=Smithsonian Magazine|publisher=Smithsonian|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techinsider.io/how-theranos-revolutionary-technology-works-2015-10|title=Here's what we know about how Theranos' 'revolutionary' technology works|work=[[Tech Insider]]|date=16 October 2015|access-date=25 July 2016|author=Loria, Kevin}}</ref> The technology has been criticized for not being [[peer review]]ed.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[James B. Stewart|Stewart, James B.]]|title=The Narrative Frays for Theranos and Elizabeth Holmes|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/30/business/the-narrative-frays-for-theranos-and-elizabeth-holmes.html|date=October 29, 2015| website=nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="Issie">{{cite web|last1=Lapowsky|first1=Issie|date=2015-10-15|title=Theranos' Scandal Exposes the Problem With Tech's Hype Cycle|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/10/theranos-scandal-exposes-the-problem-with-techs-hype-cycle/|website=Wired Magazine|accessdate=2015-11-15}}</ref> Theranos claimed to have data verifying the accuracy and reliability of its tests that would be published.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/27/business/chief-of-theranos-pledges-to-prove-blood-tests-reliability.html|title=Theranos Chief Yields to Calls for Proof of Blood Test's Reliability|date=27 October 2015|work=The New York Times|accessdate=26 December 2015}}</ref> In February 2016, Theranos announced that it would permit the Cleveland Clinic to complete a validation study of its technology.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Theranos Has Still Not Begun a Promised Validation Study|url = http://fortune.com/2016/02/02/theranos-blood-test-elizabeth-holmes/|website = Fortune|access-date = 2016-02-02}}</ref> In March, 2016, a study authored by 13 scientists appeared in the ''[[Journal of Clinical Investigation]]'', where it was stated that the company's blood test results were flagged "outside their normal range 1.6x more often than other testing services", that 68% of lab measurements evaluated "showed significant interservice (sic) variability", and that "lipid panel test results between Theranos and other clinical services" were "nonequivalent".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jci.org/articles/view/86318|title=Evaluation of direct-to-consumer low-volume lab tests in healthy adults|work=[[Journal of Clinical Investigation]]|date=28 March 2016|access-date=21 June 2017|author=Kidd, Brian et al.}}</ref> In August 2016, the company introduced a new robotic, capillary blood testing unit named miniLab to the [[American Association for Clinical Chemistry]], but did not present any data supporting the claimed abilities of the device.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/02/business/elizabeth-holmes-founder-of-theranos-falls-from-highest-perch-off-forbes-list.html|title=Elizabeth Holmes, Founder of Theranos, Falls From Highest Perch Off Forbes List|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 June 2016|access-date=25 July 2016|author=Abelson, Reed}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Langreth|first1=Robert|last2=Chen|first2=Caroline|title=Expecting Data From Theranos, Lab Experts Get New Product|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-08-01/theranos-presents-new-product-instead-of-data-backing-old-device|accessdate=1 August 2016|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=1 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Herper|first1=Matthew|title=Theranos Presents Data On New Blood Test Machine, Remains Mum On Previous Technology|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2016/08/01/theranos-presents-data-on-new-blood-test-machine-remains-mum-on-previous-technology/|accessdate=1 August 2016|publisher=Forbes|date=1 August 2016}}</ref>
==Corporate affairs== ===Location=== Theranos was headquartered in Palo Alto, California. It previously had laboratories in [[Newark, California]] and [[Scottsdale, Arizona]].<ref>{{Cite news | title = Theranos Founder Faces a Test of Technology, and Reputation | work = [[The New York Times]] | author1 = Abelson, Reed | author2 = Creswell, Julie | date = 19 December 2015 | access-date = 2 July 2016 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/20/business/theranos-founder-faces-a-test-of-technology-and-reputation.html?_r=0}}</ref>
===Management=== From its incorporation in 2003 until 2018, Holmes was the company's chief executive officer. She recruited [[Channing Robertson]], a chemical-engineering professor at Stanford, to be a technical advisor and the company's first board member during its early years. Holmes' then-boyfriend [[Ramesh Balwani|Sunny Balwani]], a software engineer 18 years her senior whom Holmes had met during high school, joined the company as its president and chief operating officer in 2009.<ref name=auletta>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/12/15/blood-simpler|title=Blood, Simpler|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=15 December 2014|access-date=31 May 2016|author=Auletta, Ken}}</ref> In July 2011, Holmes was introduced to former Secretary of State [[George Shultz]], who joined the Theranos board of directors that month.<ref name=fortune>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2014/06/12/theranos-board-directors/|title=A singular board at Theranos|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|date=12 June 2014|access-date=11 May 2016|author=Parloff, Roger}}</ref> Over the next three years, Shultz helped to introduce almost all the outside directors on the "all-star board," which included [[William Perry]] (former Secretary of Defense), [[Henry Kissinger]] (former Secretary of State), [[Sam Nunn]] (former U.S. Senator), [[Bill Frist]] (former U.S. Senator and heart-transplant surgeon), [[Gary Roughead]] (Admiral, [[United States Navy|USN]], retired), [[James Mattis]] (General, [[United States Marine Corps|USMC]]), [[Richard Kovacevich]] (former Wells Fargo Chairman and CEO) and [[Riley Bechtel]] (chairman of the board and former CEO at [[Bechtel Group]]).<ref name=fortune/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/print-edition/2013/08/02/theranos-adds-kovacevich-to-all-star.html|title=Theranos adds Kovacevich to all-star board|last=Leuty|first=Ron|date=2 August 2013|work=San Francisco Business Times|accessdate=9 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/biotech/2013/07/theranos-dick-kovacevich-james-mattis.html|title=Quiet Theranos adds former Wells chief Kovacevich, 'Mad Dog' Mattis to power-packed board|last=Leuty|first=Ron|date=29 July 2013|work=San Francisco Business Times|accessdate=9 March 2014}}</ref> The board was criticized for consisting "mainly of directors with diplomatic or military backgrounds."<ref name=never/>
In April 2016, Theranos announced its medical advisory board which included past presidents or board members of the [[American Association for Clinical Chemistry]].<ref name=fortuneparloff>{{cite web | url=http://fortune.com/2016/04/07/theranos-adds-startlingly-well-qualified-medical-board/ | title=Theranos Adds Startlingly Well-Qualified Medical Board | publisher=Fortune | date=7 April 2016 | accessdate=14 April 2016 | author=Parloff, Roger}}</ref> Members were invited to review the company's proprietary technologies and advise on the integration into clinical practice.<ref name=fortuneparloff/> The board included past presidents or board members of the American Association for Clinical Chemistry such as Susan A. Evans, [[William Foege]], former director U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC), David Helfet, director of the Orthopedic Trauma Service at the Hospital for Special Surgery and professors, Ann M. Gronowski, Larry J. Kricka, Jack Ladenson, Andy O. Miller and Steven Spitalnik.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/theranos-adds-members-to-scientific-and-medical-advisory-board-2016-4|title=Theranos just made a crucial move that could help its reputation|work=[[Business Insider]]|date=7 April 2016|access-date=9 September 2016|author=Ramsey, Lydia}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/kimberly-weisul/heavy-hitters-join-theranos-advisory-board.html|title=Heavy Hitters Join Theranos Advisory Board|work=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|date=7 April 2016|access-date=9 September 2016|author=Weisul, Kimberly}}</ref>
Balwani left his position as President and COO in May 2016. At that time, the company announced its new board members, [[Fabrizio Bonanni]] (former executive vice president of [[Amgen]]), Richard Kovacevich and William Foege, who would help to publicly introduce its technologies.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Masunaga|first1=Samantha|title=Theranos shuffles leadership; president retires|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-theranos-board-20160512-snap-story.html|website=latimes.com|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Carreyrou|first1=John|title=Theranos Executive Sunny Balwani to Depart Amid Regulatory Probes|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/theranos-executive-sunny-balwani-to-depart-amid-regulatory-probes-1463015943|website=wsj.com|accessdate=12 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=della Cava|first1=Marco|title=Theranos COO departs as embattled startup adds to board|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/05/12/theranos-coo-departs-embattled-startup-adds-board/84283766/|website=usatoday.com|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=12 May 2016|quote=Theranos also is adding former Amgen executive Fabrizio Bonanni to its board.}}</ref>
In May 2016 members of the Theranos board of directors were:<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/embattled-blood-lab-theranos-makes-a-bid-to-regain-confidence.html?_r=1 | title=Embattled Blood Lab Theranos Makes a Bid to Regain Confidence | publisher=The New York Times | date=11 May 2016 | accessdate=17 May 2016 | author=Abelson, Reed}}</ref> * Elizabeth Holmes, founder and CEO * Riley Bechtel, former Bechtel Group CEO * David Boies, a founder and the chairman of [[Boies Schiller & Flexner]] * William Foege, former director CDC * Richard Kovacevich, former Wells Fargo CEO and chairman * James Mattis, later US Secretary of Defense * Fabrizio Bonanni, former executive vice president of Amgen
In December 2016, it was announced the Theranos management team would be restructured with the departing of Riley Bechtel. In January 2017 incoming [[US Secretary of Defense]] nominee James Mattis resigned from the Theranos board. In January 2017 the Theranos board of directors included:<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ramsey|first1=Lydia|title=Theranos Dissolves High-Profile Board of Counselors|url=http://www.inc.com/business-insider/theranos-retires-board-of-counselors-leadership-kissinger-schultz.html|website=Inc.|accessdate=3 December 2016}}</ref> Elizabeth Holmes, William Foege, Fabrizio Bonanni, and [[Daniel Warmenhoven]], former [[NetApp]] CEO, who replaced Riley Bechtel
It was also announced in November 2016 that the celebrity-studded "board of counselors" would be scrapped in January 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Weaver|first1=Christopher|title=Theranos Investor Riley Bechtel Steps Down From Board|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/theranos-investor-riley-bechtel-steps-down-from-board-1480643702|website=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=3 December 2016}}</ref>
===Valuation=== Theranos raised millions of dollars in its first years. In 2004, Theranos was based in a rented basement located near the Stanford campus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/71523196-fc45-11e5-b5f5-070dca6d0a0d.html|title=Blood Simple|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=8 April 2016|subscription=yes|access-date=|author=Crow, David}}</ref> By December 2004 the company had more than $6 million from investors at a valuation of $30 million.<ref name=WSJDec>{{cite news|last1=Carreyrou|first1=John|title=At Theranos, Many Strategies and Snags|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/at-theranos-many-strategies-and-snags-1451259629?mod=e2fb|accessdate=28 December 2015|agency=The Wall Street Journal|date=27 December 2015}}</ref> The company had about $45 million total fundraising after [[Series B|Series B and Series C]] funding in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/bizwomen/news/profiles-strategies/2015/06/theranos-testing-times-lie-ahead-for-secretive.html?page=all|title=Theranos: Testing times lie ahead for secretive blood-testing firm|work=American City Business Journals|date=29 June 2015|access-date=27 September 2016|author=Leuty, Ron}}</ref> Theranos raised an additional $45 million in 2010 at a valuation of $1 billion.<ref name=WSJDec/><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2010/07/08/theranos-raises-45m-to-help-patients-track-drug-reactions/|title=Theranos raises $45M to help patients track drug reactions|accessdate=2013-09-16 | work= [[VentureBeat]] | first=Julie|last=Klein|date=2010-07-08}}</ref> The company moved to the former headquarters of [[Facebook]] in June 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/print-edition/2012/06/29/theranos-growing-close-to-home-in-palo.html|title=Theranos growing close to home in Palo Alto|work=[[Silicon Valley Business Journal]]|date=29 June 2012|access-date=27 September 2016|author=Segall, Eli}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4319110/the-fall-of-theranos-and-the-future-of-science-in-silicon-valley/|title=The Fall Of Theranos And The Future Of Science In Silicon Valley|work=[[TIME (magazine)|TIME]]|date=5 May 2016|access-date=27 September 2016|author=Grossman, Lev}}</ref> The company had significant news coverage starting in September 2013 after profiles in the ''[[San Francisco Business Times]]'' and ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.<ref name=never/> By 2014, Theranos had raised more than $400 million with an estimated value of $9 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/theranos-founder-elizabeth-holmes-is-a-billionaire-2014-9|title=This Woman's Revolutionary Idea Made Her A Billionaire – And Could Change Medicine|work=[[Business Insider]]|date=29 September 2014|access-date=27 September 2016|author=Loria, Kevin}}</ref> In 2016, ''[[Forbes]]'' revised the estimated net worth of the company to $800 million taking into account the $724 million of capital raised.<ref name="Forbes_nothing">{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2016/06/01/from-4-5-billion-to-nothing-forbes-revises-estimated-net-worth-of-theranos-founder-elizabeth-holmes|title=From $4.5 Billion To Nothing: Forbes Revises Estimated Net Worth of Theranos Founder Elizabeth Holmes|last=Herper|first=Matthew|date=June 1, 2016|website=Forbes|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 1, 2016}}</ref>
In May 2017, participating shareholders provided a release of any potential claims against Theranos in exchange for shares of the company's new [[preferred stock]]. Holders of more than 99 percent of the shares elected to participate. CEO Elizabeth Holmes contributed shares to the company and gave up [[equity (finance)|equity]] to offset potential dilution to non-participating shareholders.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170516006652/en/Theranos-Finalizes-Shareholder-Recapitalization|title=Theranos Finalizes Shareholder Recapitalization|website=www.businesswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-19}}</ref>
In May 2018 [[John Carreyrou]] reported that American business and government leaders lost more than $600 million by privately investing in Theranos.<ref name=carreyrou3>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/theranos-cost-business-and-government-leaders-more-than-600-million-1525392082 |author=[[John Carreyrou]]| title=Theranos Cost Business and Government Leaders More Than $600 Million |publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=May 3, 2018 |accessdate=May 5, 2018}}</ref> Major investments had been made by the [[Walton family]] ($150 million), [[Rupert Murdoch]] ($121 million), [[Betsy DeVos]] ($100 million), and the Cox family (of [[Cox Media Group]]) ($100 million).<ref name=carreyrou/> The final liquidation of the company in September 2018 rendered these investments completely worthless.<ref name="TheranosShutdown" />
==Contribution== John Carreyrou, the ''Wall Street Journal'' reporter whose work exposed Theranos, published a book-length treatment in May 2018 titled ''[[Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/21/books/review/bad-blood-john-carreyrou.html|title=How One Company Scammed Silicon Valley. And How It Got Caught.|date=2018-05-21|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-22|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> As of June 2016 a film version was in the works starring [[Jennifer Lawrence]] as Elizabeth Holmes, written by [[Vanessa Taylor]] and directed by [[Adam McKay]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=McNary |first1=Dave |title=Legendary Wins Bidding War for Jennifer Lawrence Movie 'Bad Blood' |url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/legendary-wins-bidding-jennifer-lawrence-movie-bad-blood-1201802332/ |website=Variety |accessdate=23 July 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160625021229/https://variety.com/2016/film/news/legendary-wins-bidding-jennifer-lawrence-movie-bad-blood-1201802332/ |archivedate=2016-06-25 |deadurl=no |date=June 23, 2016}}</ref>
[[Alex Gibney]] created a film titled “[[The Inventor: Out for Blood in Silicon Valley]]” that will make its official debut at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] in Park City, Utah in 2019.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/11/28/the-inventor-a-documentary-about-theranos-and-the-psychology-of-deception-will-premiere-at-sundance/|title=‘The Inventor,’ a documentary about Theranos and the ‘psychology of deception,’ will premiere at Sundance|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Ian Gibbons (biochemist)|Ian Gibbons]] (?–2013) – Theranos' chief scientist * [[Hematology]] * [[Medical device]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox magazine | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = | editor_title = | frequency = Weekly | circulation = 44,351 (2013) | category = [[Business journalism|Business magazine]] | company = [[Roularta Media Group]] | publisher = Roularta Printing | founded = {{start date and age|1975}} | firstdate = | finaldate = | country = [[Belgium]] | based = [[City of Brussels|Brussels]] | language = [[Dutch language|Dutch]] | website = [http://trends.knack.be/economie/ ''Trends''] | issn = | oclc = }} '''''Trends''''' is a weekly Dutch language business and finance magazine published in [[City of Brussels|Brussels]], [[Belgium]]. It is the only business and finance magazine in the country.<ref>{{cite web|author=Karin Raeymaeckers|title=Media landscapes. Belgium|url=http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/belgium|work=European Journalism Centre|accessdate=20 April 2015}}</ref>
==History and profile== ''Trends'' was established in 1975.<ref name=hisrm>{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.roularta.be/en/home/RC-1184690768636.html?title=Copyright|work=Roularta Media Group|accessdate=14 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209081702/http://www.roularta.be/en/home/RC-1184690768636.html?title=Copyright|archivedate=9 December 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=memm>{{cite web|title=Magazines membres|url=http://www.theppress.be/febelmag/fr/Magazines-membres-52/Trends-151/|work=The Ppress|accessdate=5 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713080606/http://theppress.be/febelmag/fr/Magazines-membres-52/Trends-151/|archivedate=13 July 2014}}</ref> The magazine is owned by [[Roularta Media Group]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Media in Europe: The Big Picture of Ownership|url=http://www.ifj.org/fileadmin/images/EFJ/EFJ_documents/Reports/Media_Power_in_Europe.pdf|work=International Federation of Journalists|accessdate=29 April 2015|location=Brussels|date=2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Peggy Valcke|author2=Eva Lievens|title=Media Law in Belgium|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wEnVkg3e8X8C&pg=PA28|accessdate=14 January 2015|date=31 July 2010|publisher=Kluwer Law International|isbn=978-90-411-3329-8|page=28}}</ref> and is published weekly by Roularta Printing company.<ref name=afp/> In its initial phase the magazine was published on a biweekly basis.<ref name=hisrm/> It offers business news<ref name=rmg>{{cite web|title=Trends|url=http://www.roularta.be/en/read-e/trends-en/Products-1194555827087-RC.html?Parent|work=Roularta Media Group|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> and targets business executives, managers, [[entrepreneurs]] and professionals.<ref name=afp>{{cite web|title=News|url=http://www.affinity-primemedia.ch/gb/belgium.html|work=Affinity-Primemedia|accessdate=15 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115095223/http://www.affinity-primemedia.ch/gb/belgium.html|archivedate=15 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The headquarters of ''Trends'' is in Brussels.<ref name=memm/><ref>{{cite web|title=Trends|url=http://www.publicitas.com/spain/media-solutions/factsheet/?PARAM1=TB3TB1#.VLbCh2SsXRA|work=Publicitas|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> The magazine publishes a list, Trends Manager of the Year, in the fields of [[economy]], [[politics]] and [[finance]] each year.<ref name=rmg/> The magazine has two main supplements, ''MoneyTalk'' and ''Trends Style''.<ref name=rmg/> The latter began to be published separately in 2010 in addition to being a [[Supplement (publishing)|supplement]] of ''Trends''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Belgium: Roularta re-organises its business magazines|url=http://www.publicitas.com/spain/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=41570&title=belgium-roularta-re-organises-its-business-magazines#.VLbC_GSsXRA|accessdate=14 January 2015|work=Publicitas|date=10 June 2010}}</ref>
==Circulation== ''Trends'' had a circulation of 42,658 copies in 1998 and 43,775 copies in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|title=Annual Report|url=https://bib.kuleuven.be/files/ebib/jaarverslagen/Roularta_1999eng.pdf|work=Roularta Media Group|accessdate=23 March 2015|date=1999}}</ref> The circulation of the weekly was 37,270 copies in 2010 and 37,113 copies in 2011.<ref name=ifabc14>{{cite web|title=Top 50 Magazines|url=http://ifabc.org/site/assets/media/Top-50-magazines-30042014.xlsx|work=IFABC|accessdate=22 March 2015|date=30 April 2014}}</ref> It was 37,764 copies in 2012.<ref name=ifabc14/> The magazine had a circulation of 44,351 copies in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Belgium: Magazine market|url=http://system24.ilsole24ore.com/media/180862/mercatobelgamagazines.pdf|work=Il Sole 24 Ore|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of magazines in Belgium]]
